articles.headline: Hillary Clinton Struggles to Define a Legacy in Progress
articles.snippet: Mrs. Clinton may face a dilemma as she recounts her record before a possible White House bid: Much of her work as secretary of state either is unfinished or went awry.
articles.abstract: Mrs. Clinton may face a dilemma as she recounts her record before a possible White House bid: Much of her work as secretary of state either is unfinished or went awry.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was a simple question to someone accustomed to much tougher ones: What was her proudest achievement as secretary of state? But for a moment, Hillary Rodham Clinton, appearing recently before a friendly audience at a women’s forum in Manhattan, seemed flustered.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Amy Chozick

articles.headline: Yellen Says Job Weakness Forestalls Raising Rates
articles.snippet: In a speech in New York, Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said the labor market still needed a lift from monetary policy, despite an improving economy.
articles.abstract: In a speech in New York, Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said the labor market still needed a lift from monetary policy, despite an improving economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as a number of indicators point to better economic times ahead, the chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, Janet L. Yellen, reiterated on Wednesday that she expected interest rates to remain very low until the recovery is on a more secure footing and the American economy is more fully involving available workers and other resources.

articles.headline: For Young Traders, a Market Where Air Jordans Are Blue Chips
articles.snippet: Bartering and selling at conventions and online, the thousands of mostly teenage “sneakerheads” have perfected the art of trading up.
articles.abstract: Bartering and selling at conventions and online, the thousands of mostly teenage “sneakerheads” have perfected the art of trading up.
articles.lead_paragraph: With sneakers slung around their shoulders and pockets full of cash, young boys huddle in hotel ballrooms and high school gyms, shouting and bartering as if they belong on a trading room floor.

articles.headline: Earnings and Sales From Google Disappoint
articles.snippet: As Internet users migrate to mobile devices, Google earns less on its ads, and as the dominant player, growth opportunities are increasingly rare.
articles.abstract: As Internet users migrate to mobile devices, Google earns less on its ads, and as the dominant player, growth opportunities are increasingly rare.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Alexander the Great is said to have wept because he ran out of kingdoms to conquer. Google is eager to avoid such a miserable fate.

articles.headline: When ‘Liking’ a Brand Online Voids the Right to Sue
articles.snippet: The food company General Mills added language to its website to alert customers that they cannot take legal action against the company if they download coupons, enter a contest or connect with it in other ways.
articles.abstract: The food company General Mills added language to its website to alert customers that they cannot take legal action against the company if they download coupons, enter a contest or connect with it in other ways.
articles.lead_paragraph: Might downloading a 50-cent coupon for Cheerios cost you legal rights?

articles.headline: Russia Economy Worsens Even Before Sanctions Hit
articles.snippet: With the country’s long-troubled economy teetering on the edge of recession, average Russians are feeling the pinch, even before the bite of Western sanctions over Crimea.
articles.abstract: With the country’s long-troubled economy teetering on the edge of recession, average Russians are feeling the pinch, even before the bite of Western sanctions over Crimea.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Margarita R. Zobnina, a professor of marketing here, has been watching the Russian economy’s gathering woes with mounting alarm: friends who have moved abroad with no plans to return; others who put off new business ventures because of rising uncertainty. Meanwhile, Ms. Zobnina and her husband, Alexander, also a professor, have rented a safe deposit box to hold foreign cash as a hedge against the declining ruble.

articles.headline: Pensioners in Detroit Rejoice, Though Deal Is Far From Done
articles.snippet: A day after Detroit scaled back the large pension benefit cuts it had proposed, the bankrupt city fended off charges that it had caved in to retirees in ways that could come back to haunt it.
articles.abstract: A day after Detroit scaled back the large pension benefit cuts it had proposed, the bankrupt city fended off charges that it had caved in to retirees in ways that could come back to haunt it.
articles.byline: By Steven Yaccino and Monica Davey

articles.headline: Hungary’s Central Bank Seizes Bold Strategies
articles.snippet: Critics claim the central bank has lost its independence under Gyorgy Matolcsy, whose policies have included aggressive rate cuts.
articles.abstract: Critics claim the central bank has lost its independence under Gyorgy Matolcsy, whose policies have included aggressive rate cuts.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — Few central bankers are as quotable as Gyorgy Matolcsy.

articles.headline: Human Error Suspected as Hope Fades in Korean Ferry Sinking
articles.snippet: Evidence is growing that human error contributed to one of South Korea’s worst disasters in recent decades, a ferry sinking from which 271 people are still missing.
articles.abstract: Evidence is growing that human error contributed to one of South Korea’s worst disasters in recent decades, a ferry sinking from which 271 people are still missing.
articles.lead_paragraph: JINDO, South Korea — The captain was among the first to flee. Only a couple of the 44 life rafts aboard were deployed. The hundreds of passengers were instructed over the intercom to “stay inside and wait” as the ship leaned to one side and began to sink, dragging scores of students down with it.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun, Su-Hyun Lee and Jiha Ham

articles.headline: Walmart Will Enter Cash Wiring Business
articles.snippet: Fees for the service will be $4.50 for up to $50 transferred and $9.50 for amounts above that, up to $900.
articles.abstract: Fees for the service will be $4.50 for up to $50 transferred and $9.50 for amounts above that, up to $900.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a move that threatens to upend another piece of the financial services industry, Walmart, the country’s largest retailer, announced on Thursday that it would allow customers to make store-to-store money transfers within the United States at cut-rate fees.
